meanings.definition: The state or condition of being stuck or unable to move.
meanings.sent1: The stictions of the old door made it hard to open.
meanings.sent2: The glue's stictions kept the pieces firmly together.
meanings.sent3: The stictions of the gum on his shoe caused a funny walk.
meanings.sent4: The stictions of fear held her back from taking risks.
meanings.sent5: The stictions of the mud made it impossible to escape.

meanings.definition: A force that resists motion between two surfaces in contact.
meanings.sent1: She had to overcome the stictions between the magnets to separate them.
meanings.sent2: The stictions between the tires and the wet road made driving difficult.
meanings.sent3: The stictions between the puzzle pieces made it challenging to solve.
meanings.sent4: The stictions between the conflicting ideas created tension in the room.
meanings.sent5: The stictions between the gears slowed down the machine's operation.

meanings.definition: The action of sticking together or adhering.
meanings.sent1: The stictions of the tape kept the poster on the wall.
meanings.sent2: The stictions between the pages of the book made it hard to turn.
meanings.sent3: The stictions of the stickers made them difficult to remove.
meanings.sent4: The stictions of the wet paint caused the pages to stick together.
meanings.sent5: The stictions of the Velcro made it easy to fasten the shoes.
